temple_name: Sri Venkateswara Temple - Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanam
temple_legend: The Tirumala Venkateswara Temple, dedicated to Lord Venkateswara, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, is located on the seventh peak, Venkatadri, of the Tirupati Hill in Andhra Pradesh, India. According to legends, the sage Bhrigu, in his quest to find the most supreme among the Hindu trinity Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, kicked Lord Vishnu on the chest. Instead of getting angry, Vishnu massaged Bhrigu's foot, which led the sage to declare Vishnu as the supreme deity. However, Goddess Lakshmi, furious at the insult, left Vaikuntha and descended to Earth. Vishnu, unable to bear the separation, descended to Earth and settled on the Tirumala Hills, taking the form of Srinivasa. A Chola king named Tondaiman, guided by Vishnu in a dream, built a temple for him. The story also involves a Chola king's cow emptying her milk at the anthill where Srinivasa resided, leading to the discovery of Srinivasa and his marriage to Padmavati, the king's daughter. To pay for the wedding, Vishnu borrowed money from Kubera, promising to repay the debt until the end of Kali Yuga, which is why devotees' offerings are believed to go towards repaying this debt. The temple is a significant pilgrimage site, attracting millions of devotees each year who seek the blessings of Lord Venkateswara and offer donations, considering it highly auspicious.
significance: The Tirumala Venkateswara Temple, dedicated to Lord Venkateswara, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, is located on the seventh peak, Venkatadri, of the Tirupati Hill in Andhra Pradesh, India. According to legends, the sage Bhrigu, in his quest to find the most supreme among the Hindu trinity Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, kicked Lord Vishnu on the chest. Instead of getting angry, Vishnu massaged Bhrigu's foot, which led the sage to declare Vishnu as the supreme deity. However, Goddess Lakshmi, furious at the insult, left Vaikuntha and descended to Earth. Vishnu, unable to bear the separation, descended to Earth and settled on the Tirumala Hills, taking the form of Srinivasa. A Chola king named Tondaiman, guided by Vishnu in a dream, built a temple for him. The story also involves a Chola king's cow emptying her milk at the anthill where Srinivasa resided, leading to the discovery of Srinivasa and his marriage to Padmavati, the king's daughter. To pay for the wedding, Vishnu borrowed money from Kubera, promising to repay the debt until the end of Kali Yuga, which is why devotees' offerings are believed to go towards repaying this debt. The temple is a significant pilgrimage site, attracting millions of devotees each year who seek the blessings of Lord Venkateswara and offer donations, considering it highly auspicious. The significance of the temple lies in its rich mythology, religious importance, and the belief that offerings contribute to repaying Lord Vishnu's divine debt, making it a revered site of devotion and charity.
timings_mon_thrus: Round The Clock Based On Your Slotted Sarva Darshan or Special Entry Darshan Tickets
timings_fri: Round The Clock Based On Your Slotted Sarva Darshan or Special Entry Darshan Tickets
annaprasadam_details: The Annaprasadam program at Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) provides free meals to thousands of devotees daily at the Matrusri Tarigonda Vengamamba Annaprasadam Complex and other locations, serving breakfast from 8:30 AM to 10:30 AM, lunch from 11:00 AM to 4:00 PM, and dinner from 6:00 PM to 11:00 PM with high standards of hygiene, supported by staff and volunteers, funded by donations, with special menus on festivals, emphasizing spiritual merit, community service, and inclusiveness, ensuring no devotee goes hungry and everyone can partake without discrimination.

temple_legend: Sri Vakulamatha Temple, TTD is located on a hillock at Peruru, Pathakalva, around 5 KM from Tirupati. Maha-Samprokshana was conducted successfully from 18-06-2022 to 23-06-2022 at Sri Vakulmatha Temple and the temple opened for visiting pilgrims from 24-06-2022 onwards. Vakula Devi is Lord Venkateswara’s receptive mother. Previously, Yasoda Devi brought Sri Vishnu up in the manifested type of Sri Krishna and, not totally fulfilled to see his presence, wished him to go on for quite a while. He conceded her desire in a gift expressing that in another manifestation he would satisfy her desire. As per this help, Sri Maha Vishnu as Lord Srinivasa presently satisfied her. Yashoda Devi, brought into the world as Vakulamata, partook in his presence while serving him. In the Kali Yuga, Vakula Devi organized the ruler’s marriage with Sri Padmavathi Devi. Along these lines Vakula Devi satisfies her desire to observe Lord Venkateswara’s Kalyanam.
significance: The significance of Sri Vakulamatha Temple lies in its association with Vakula Devi, the receptive mother of Lord Venkateswara, fulfilling divine promises, connecting devotees to Lord Venkateswara's life, symbolizing maternal affection, fulfilling desires, cultural heritage, celebrating Maha-Samprokshana, and serving as a symbol of divine grace and blessings, offering devotees spiritual solace and connection with the divine motherly energy.
annaprasadam_details: Everyday, Annadanam is being conducted at Sri Vakulamatha Temple, Patakalva at 11:30 AM. Around 150-200 visiting pilgrims have been availed the Anna Prasadam.The Visiting Pilgrim/donor can donate for the above Anna Prasadam on a particular day of their choice(on their birthdays, wedding Anniversary or any other auspicious days) and they can also participate during Anna Prasada Vithranam. They may contact Temple Inspector( Ph No.9704433094) for donation related queries/any other information.

temple_legend: Tiruchanoor, one of the oldest pilgrim towns located 5km away from Tirupati, is the abode of Goddess Sri Padmavathi Devi, beloved consort of Lord Venkateswara, popularly known as 'Alar melmangapuram' or Alimelumangapuram. According to temple legend, Goddess Mahalakshmi emerged from the golden lotus as Padmavathi Devi at the centre of Padmasarovaram-the temple tank, making this place famous by the name 'Alarmelmangapuram'. Pilgrims believe in visiting Padmavathi Devi to seek Her blessings before visiting Lord Venkateswara at Tirumala. The advent of Goddess Padmavathi Devi is narrated in puranas, where a pious Brahmin named Pundarika, after years of prayers, got a son named Madhava who later deviated from righteousness, leading to his wandering like a mad man.Once, following pilgrims to Tirumala, Akasharaja bathed in Sudarshana Lake and heard a celestial voice directing him to seek Lord Varaha Swamy's blessings. Born to King Mitravarman, he married Dharanidevi but had no children. Through a yagna, they found Padamavathi in a lotus. Lord Venkateshwara married her later. Temple built by Tondaman Chakravarthi, Padmavathi's brother.
significance: The divine emergence of Sri Padmavathi Devi is known through holy texts like 'Varaha Puranam', 'Skandha Puranam', 'Padma Puranam', 'Sri Venkatachala Mahatmyam', Sri Nammalvar’s 'Tiruvaimoli', Sri Parasara Bhattar’s 'Sri Gunarathnakosham', Sri Vedanta Desika’s 'Sri Sthavam', Sri Prathivada Bhayankara Annan’s 'Suprabhatam', etc. According to legend, Sage Bhrigu kicked Lord Vishnu, causing Sri Lakshmi to leave Vaikuntam. Lord Vishnu then came to 'Venkatachalam' and stayed with Sri Varaha Swamy.Searching for Sri Lakshmi, Lord Vishnu performed penance for twelve years, guided by a celestial voice. Sri Lakshmi asked Him to create a lake, where she would manifest. He created a pushkarini with His instrument 'Kuntalam' and a Golden Lotus. Sri Padmavathi Devi manifested on Kartika Shukla Paksha Panchami. Sri Nammalwar wrote about Her as Lord 'Srinivasa's consort. Sri Padmavathi Devi is also known as Hrudaya Lakshmi or Vyuha Lakshmi.She is called Sri Padmavathi Devi, daughter of Akasharaja, born with the 'amsa' of Vedavathi. Divine rituals follow 'Pancharathra Agama' tradition.
annaprasadam_details: Everyday, Annadanam is being conducted at Sri Padmavathi Ammavari Temple, Tiruchanoor. . Around 3500 visiting pilgrims during week days and 5000 pilgrims during weekends have been availed the Anna Prasadam.

temple_legend: Tiruchanoor, one of the oldest pilgrim towns located 5km away from Tirupati, is the abode of Goddess Sri Padmavathi Devi, beloved consort of Lord Venkateswara, popularly known as 'Alar melmangapuram' or Alimelumangapuram. According to temple legend, Goddess Mahalakshmi emerged from the golden lotus as Padmavathi Devi at the centre of Padmasarovaram-the temple tank, making this place famous by the name 'Alarmelmangapuram'. Pilgrims believe in visiting Padmavathi Devi to seek Her blessings before visiting Lord Venkateswara at Tirumala. The advent of Goddess Padmavathi Devi is narrated in puranas, where a pious Brahmin named Pundarika, after years of prayers, got a son named Madhava who later deviated from righteousness, leading to his wandering like a mad man.Once, following pilgrims to Tirumala, Akasharaja bathed in Sudarshana Lake and heard a celestial voice directing him to seek Lord Varaha Swamy's blessings. Born to King Mitravarman, he married Dharanidevi but had no children. Through a yagna, they found Padamavathi in a lotus. Lord Venkateshwara married her later. Temple built by Tondaman Chakravarthi, Padmavathi's brotherWhen South India was invaded by Muslim rulers, the presiding deity of Chidambaram, Sri Govindaraja Swamy was brought and kept safely in Tirupati. After the situation at Chidambaram returned to normalcy, the vigraham of Lord Sri Govindaraja Swamy was taken back to Chidambaram from Tirupati. One day, Sri Ramanujacharya had a vision of Lord Govindaraja Swamy in his dream. He was advised by the Lord to make arrangements for Him to reside in Tirupati. Sri Ramanujacharya, by then was aware of Sri Govindaraja Swamy’s stay at Tirupati during Muslim invasion. He, with the help of the king visited the place he saw in his dream. To their astonishment, they found the vigraham of Lord Govindaraja Swamy in that place. Sri Ramanujacharya advised the king to construct a temple for the Lord and houses for the people, who perform kainkaryam in the Sri Govindaraja Swamy temple.
significance: As per Aithihyam it is said that, Sri Govindaraja Swamy is the elder brother of Sri Venkateswara Swamy who accomplished the ever magnificent marriage between Sri Venkateswara Swamy and Padmavathi Ammavaru. Sri Govindaraja Swamy was the caretaker of massive wealth being obtained from king Kubera for conducting the wedding. He efficiently utilised this wealth to conduct one of the most glorious weddings of the history.Hence Sri Govindaraja Swamy is considered to be the god who helps you to elevate your wealth and manage the wealth acquired efficiently.This temple is a remarkable achievement of the ancient south Indian architecture. It's tall and remarkable seven storied outer Gopuram with 11 kalasas was dated back to 14-15th century. This temple is one of the huge temples in Chittoor district. This Gopuram is enriched with the handwork depicting the scenes from Bhagavata, Ramayana and Lord Sri Venketeswara swamy's life.The tall primary Gopuram is followed by a smaller but no less remarkable inner Gopuram. The inner Gopuram holds a decorative courtyard with a spacious inner stone hall, which protects the devotee's even during the busy festival times. The following are the important festivals that are being celebrated in Sri Govindaraja Swamy Temple, Tirupati: a) Vaisakha Festival (Annual Brahmotsavam ) b) Float Festival c) Adhyayanotsavam d) Thiruvadipuram e) Godaparinayam f) Sri Salai Nachiyar Panguni Uttiram Festival g) Rathasapthami h) Jyestabhishekam i) Anivara Asthanam j) Neeratotsavam k) Buggotsavam l) Pavithrosthavam m) Pushpayagam In addition to the above, Parveta Utsavam and Ponna Kalva utsavams are also being conducted every year. Further, Pournami Garudaseva is conducted on the Pournami day of every month for the convenience of the devotees, who fulfill their vows to Lord Sri Govindarja Swamy during processions. Besides this, each Alwar Sathumorai and Thirunakshatram are conducted for 10 days in each of the 12 Alwar Temples.
annaprasadam_details: The Sri Govindaraja Swamy temple in Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh serves free Annaprasadam to around 2,000 devotees every day from 11 AM to 4 PM at Sri Nammalwar Sannidhi on the North Mada Street of the temple. The temple uses a POS machine to distribute tokens for Annaprasadam.
contact_details: Pilgrims can reach out to the following contact number incase of any enquiries: Contact No.0877-2277777, 09652667605

temple_legend: This Temple was built during the first Vijayanagar Dynasty in 14th Century. The Temple is in the list of Protected Monuments of National Importance and taken over by the TTD on 26-4-1967, for maintaining and arranging necessary daily rituals of the Deity and other customary acts of the Temple. The ancient pathway ‘Sri Vari Mettu’ (Lord’s Step) has got its name, according to the Legend, as the Lord himself climbed the Sacred Hills through this way; which is just 6 km away from this Srinivasa Mangapuram Temple. Through this pathway one can easily reach Tirumala Hills within an hour. This pathway is being developed by the TTD in such a way, beautifully on par with popular path way (Alipiri) by providing all facilities to the devotees.
significance: Lord Srinivasa after married Sri Padmavathi is said to have come to Mangapuram on his way to Tirumala Hills and stayed near Agastyamuni Ashram. Lord Srinivasa while leaving Agasthyamuni Ashram to the Seven Hills blessed his devotees with two boons. One is that who are not able to climb the Hills and have his darshan at Tirumala Hills, He will give darshan at SrinivasaMangapuram itself as Archavatara.Second one is Remedy for marriage obstacles – Those who face obstacles in getting their kalyanam (marriage); such obstacles will be vanished with his darshan at Srinivasa Mangapuram. Till today, the devotees are performing Srinivasa Kalyanam and wearing ‘kalyana-kankanam’ (sacred thread) to overcome their marriage obstacles.The most important festival in the Temple is Sakshatkara Vaibhavam (i.e., the day on which the Lord revealed Himself) conducted during AshadaMasam (July) every year and the other important festivals are Annual Brahmotsavam, Pavithrotsavams, Vaikunta Ekadasi and Parveta Utsavam.
annaprasadam_details: Everyday, Annadanam is being conducted at Sri Kalyana Venkateswara Swamy Temple, Srinivasa Mangapuram at 12:30 PM. Around 300-400 visiting pilgrims have been availed the Anna Prasadam.The Visiting Pilgrim/donor can donate for the above Anna Prasadam on a particular day of their choice(on their birthdays, wedding Anniversary or any other auspicious days) and they can also participate during Anna Prasada Vithranam. They may contact Temple Inspector(Ph No.9182297204) for donation related queries/any other information.

temple_legend: Sri Kapileswara Swamy Vari Temple and Kapilatheertham is one of the famous 108 sacred Theerthams on Tirumala Hills located at Tirupati maintained by the TTD. The idol is believed to be installed by Kapila Muni and hence Lord Shiva here is referred to as Kapileswara. The temple stands at the entrance to a mountain cave in one of the steep and vertical faces at the foot of the Tirumala hills which are part of Seshachalam Hills, where the waters of the mountain stream fall directly into Temple steps as the Pushkarini known as “KapilaTheertham” and also as “AlwarTheertham”. A huge stone statue of a seated bull “Nandhi”, Lord’s Shiva’s steed, greets devotees and passersby at the entrance to the temple. Accordingly to Temple Legend Kapila Muni had performed penance to Lord Shiva at this place and blessed with KapilaMuni’s Pious, Lord Siva and Parvathi presented themselves. Theswamy Lingam is believed to self- manifested (Swayambhu). Kapila Muni is believed to emerged through theBilam(Cavity)in the Pushkarini (Theertham) on the earth. A prominent ritual at this temple happens on the full moon day during the month of kartheeka on the occassaion of its Mukkoti. All the Theerthas situated in the three worlds are believed to merge into the holy water of Kapilathhertha at noon for about 10 Ghatikas (1 Ghatika equal to 24 minutes).There is a belief that when devotees take bath in Kapilatheertham during this time they will attain the Brahmaloka or salvation from the cycle of births and deaths and will get rid. Hence, the Kapilatheertham Temple is attracting the devotees and are being approached across the country for offering their prayers to Lord Shiva.
significance: Accordingly to Temple Legend Kapila Muni had performed penance to Lord Shiva at this place and blessed with KapilaMuni’s Pious, Lord Siva and Parvathi presented themselves. Theswamy Lingam is believed to self- manifested (Swayambhu). Kapila Muni is believed to emerged through theBilam(Cavity)in the Pushkarini (Theertham) on the earth. A prominent ritual at this temple happens on the full moon day during the month of kartheeka on the occassaion of its Mukkoti. All the Theerthas situated in the three worlds are believed to merge into the holy water of Kapilathhertha at noon for about 10 Ghatikas (1 Ghatika equal to 24 minutes).There is a belief that when devotees take bath in Kapilatheertham during this time they will attain the Brahmaloka or salvation from the cycle of births and deaths and will get rid. Hence, the Kapilatheertham Temple is attracting the devotees and are being approached across the country for offering their prayers to Lord Shiva.
annaprasadam_details: The Visiting Pilgrim/donor can donate for the above Anna Prasadam on a particular day of their choice(on their birthdays, wedding Anniversary or any other auspicious days) and they can also participate during Anna Prasada Vithranam.

temple_legend: In token of the visit of Seetha, Rama and Lakshmana to this place, their idols were consecrated and in later days the emperor Janamejaya renovated this temple as per the evidence available in “Sawal Jawab patti”.According to the local peoples belief, Jambavantha consecrated the idols in the temple and later that was renovated by emperor Janamejaya. • It was later believed that the idlos were found by the emperor Janamejaya in the local Ramachandra Pushkarini, Tirupati (a sacred tank). • According to the inscriptions, Sri Narasimha Mudiliar constructed this temple in the year Saka 1402(1480 A.D.). The sculpture of this temple was identified and designed during the Vijayanagara period.
significance: In this temple Sri Kodandarama Swamy with Lakshmana Swamy to his left remains in a standing posture as Archa murties. As the tradition of Vaikhanasa agama Goddess Seetha Devi was placed to the right side of Sri Kodandarama Swamy.The Panchaberams were also installed in this temple as in Tirumala Temple. These panchaberams – Mulavarlu, Koutuka murites, Utsava murthies, Snapana murthies, Bali murhties (Dhruva murthies) are being worshipped daily. Sri Bhakthaanjaneya Swamy, Sri Chakratthalwar and Sri Thandava Krishna (Sayana seva) can aslo seen in this temple.
annaprasadam_details: Two days in a week, Annadanam is being conducted at this temple premises at 12:15 PM. Around 200-300 visiting pilgrims have been availed the Anna Prasadam.The Visiting Pilgrim/donor can donate for the above Anna Prasadam on a particular day of their choice(on their birthdays, wedding Anniversary or any other auspicious days) and they can also participate during Anna Prasada Vithranam.

temple_legend: Sri Tataiahgunta Gangamma is the Grama Devatha (village deity) of Tirupati city. Legend has it that during the rule of Palegondulu in Tirupati and its surrounding areas, there was rampant harassment of women. In the village of Avilala, Goddess Gangamma was born and grew into a beautiful woman. When Palegondulu attempted to harm her, she used her divine grace and power to threaten him, causing him to hide in a remote location.To draw Palegondulu out of hiding, Gangamma devised the 'Ganga Jathara', a festival where people in Tirupati dressed in peculiar costumes and performed rituals for seven days. On the seventh day, Palegondulu emerged from hiding and was defeated by Goddess Gangamma, ensuring the welfare and safety of all people.
significance: Ganga Jatara, the folk festival of Tirupati, commences with the formal Chatimpu (announcement) around midnight on Tuesday. Organized by the Theallaya Mirasi Achari family, specifically Eepur Achari and Kasi Achari, they oversee all arrangements for the festival.This festival, held annually in May, holds great significance for the people of Tirupati and is centered around the Tataiahgunta Gangamma Temple, located on the banks of Thathaya gunta.The rituals begin with priests performing initiatory ceremonies and tying 'Vadibalu' to the 'Viswaroopa Sthambam' in front of the temple, marking the start of the festivities. Men carrying dappus roam through the old town announcing the festival's commencement, urging residents not to leave town until its conclusion.A highlight of the festival is the creation of a traditional large clay idol of the goddess at the temple's entrance. Throughout the festival, devotees flock to pray and offer pongal, sarees, turmeric, kumkum, and other items to the goddess.On the final day, the clay idol on the portico is ceremoniously smashed into pieces at an auspicious moment. Devotees eagerly collect these sacred remnants, either to preserve in their 'Puja' rooms or to dissolve in water.While animal sacrifice is banned, historically, goats and fowls were sacrificed discreetly in a corner of the temple premises.Celebrated annually on the 13th, 14th, and 15th of May across various areas in the undivided Chittoor district, such as Tirupati, Chittoor, and Palamaner, in Andhra Pradesh, India, Ganga Jatara remains a cherished cultural and religious event.

temple_legend: ISKCON Tirupati, also known as the Sri Radha Govinda Temple, is a spiritual sanctuary in Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh, dedicated to Lord Krishna and Radha. Founded as part of the global ISKCON movement by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, the temple blends traditional South Indian architecture with modern aesthetics. It serves as a hub for spiritual practices, cultural festivities, and community service, attracting devotees and tourists alike with its serene ambiance and devotion to Lord Krishna.
significance: Lord Krishna holds immense significance in Hinduism as the eighth incarnation of Lord Vishnu, embodying divine love, wisdom, and righteousness. His teachings in the Bhagavad Gita on duty (dharma), devotion (bhakti), and selfless action (karma) resonate deeply, guiding followers on paths of spiritual fulfillment. Krishna's playful childhood exploits, his role as protector and advisor in the Mahabharata, and his universal appeal as a symbol of love and compassion make him a revered deity whose influence extends beyond religious boundaries, shaping culture, literature, and philosophy across generations.
annaprasadam_details: In Tirupati, last year ISKCON distributed more than 60 lakh plates of prasadam meal in and outside the temple premises. The above mentioned prasada meals were distributed to pilgrims, temple devotees, and underprivileged during several festivals, as part of Anna Dan Seva initiative during Makar Sankranti, at temple anniversary celebrations, and many other occasions. Donate towards free and tasty lunch prasadam served every day to hundreds of pilgrims visiting the temple. The devotees are served sumptuous prasadam consisting of rice, sambar, sabji, pongal, and buttermilk.

temple_legend: This 1000-year old historicil temple is a sub-shrine of TTD that comes under the group of temples in Tiruchanoor. The legend says, after Sri Venkateswara marrying to Padmavati Devi at Narayanavanam while on His way to Tirumala to meet Vakula Mata in Tirumala, happens to visit this place where Sri Siddheswara Swamy was offering penance. Upon his request, the Lord appears as Sri Prasanna Venkateswara with one hand in Abhaya Hasta (blessing pose). The rulers of Karvetinagaram has constructed a temple and performed all festivals on par with Tirumala, Tirupati and Tiruchanoor in this temple. Besides the main deity,' there are temples for Goddess Padmavati, Andal Sri Goda Devi within the temple complex and a temple dedicated to Lord Hanuman outside the temple.Every year during the month of Jyesta, the annual brahmotsavams are observed with aplomb' The other festivals including Radha Saptami, Ugadi, Anivara Asthanam, Pavitrotsavams, Vaikuntha Ekadasi etc. are also observed in a big way.This temple is also covered under AP Tourism's Alaya Darsini Tour Package.
significance: This historic temple, dating back 1000 years, is a sub-shrine of TTD (Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanam) and is part of the group of temples in Tiruchanoor. According to legend, after Sri Venkateswara married Padmavati Devi at Narayanavanam, while en route to Tirumala to meet Vakula Mata, he visited this place where Sri Siddheswara Swamy was performing penance. Upon Siddheswara Swamy's request, the Lord manifested as Sri Prasanna Venkateswara with one hand in Abhaya Hasta (blessing pose).The rulers of Karvetinagaram constructed a temple here and conducted all festivals on par with Tirumala, Tirupati, and Tiruchanoor. Apart from the main deity, there are temples dedicated to Goddess Padmavati and Andal Sri Goda Devi within the temple complex, and a temple dedicated to Lord Hanuman outside.Every year during the month of Jyesta, the annual Brahmotsavams are celebrated with grandeur. Other festivals such as Radha Saptami, Ugadi, Anivara Asthanam, Pavitrotsavams, Vaikuntha Ekadasi, etc., are also observed with enthusasm. This temple is also included in AP Tourism's Alaya Darsini Tour Package.
annaprasadam_details: Everyday, Annadanam is being conducted at Sri Prasanna Venkateswara Swamy Temple, Appalayagunta at 12:30 PM. Around 200-300 pilgrims on weekdays and 500-600 pilgrims on Saturday have been availed the Anna Prasadam.The Visiting Pilgrim/donor can donate for the above Anna Prasadam on a particular day of their choice(on their birthdays, wedding Anniversary or any other auspicious days) and they can also participate during Anna Prasada Vithranam. They may contact Temple Inspector(Ph No.9790816788) for donation related queries/any other information.
